content: Human history began in Africa, with human ancestors evolving into homosapiens around 200,000 years ago. Small bands of modern humans migrated out of Africa 50,000 to 100,000 years ago, becoming ancestors to all human populations. The Bantu people of West Africa expanded their settlement 2,500-5,000 years ago, becoming the predominant group in sub-Saharan Africa. Nilo-Saharan language speakers are found in the Sahel grasslands and parts of eastern Africa. The Bantu people became the predominant group in sub-Saharan Africa, while Nilo-Saharan languages are found in the Sahel grasslands and parts of eastern Africa. The origins of iron use in Africa are uncertain, but by 500 BC, the Bantu had mastered iron smelting, leading to successful agriculture and expansion. By 1500, an estimated 47 million Africans were living in farming communities across the continent, growing a variety of crops including maize and peanuts. Some crops were introduced through contacts with the Indian Ocean region and southeast Asia. Many farmers also had cattle, although the tsetse fly limited cattle farming in certain regions. By 1500, an estimated 47 million Africans lived in farming communities across the continent, exchanging goods with pastoralists. Large towns and cities did not develop due to disease-causing organisms. Loyalties to large ethnic groups were largely absent in pre-colonial Africa. In pre-colonial Africa, loyalties to large ethnic groups were largely absent. Instead, African loyalties were embedded in extended families, clans, and patron-client relationships. Powerful individuals or chiefs, known as "big men," exerted influence over wide areas through various means. In pre-colonial Africa, powerful individuals known as "big men" consolidated authority through conquest and alliance, leading to the development of African kingdoms like the Kongo kingdom. These kingdoms showcased great artistic achievements, such as naturalistic bronze castings in Benin and stylized Congolese masks. The Atlantic slave trade is believed to have started in 1441. The Atlantic slave trade began in 1441 when a man and a woman were captured in Western Sahara and taken to Portugal. Over the next 400 years, between 10-13 million people were taken from Africa, with most going to Brazil and the Caribbean. In 1807, the British parliament voted to end the slave trade, leading to the Royal Navy intercepting over 1,600 ships and freeing 160,000 captives. Despite efforts to halt the trade, slavery continued in the Americas until its abolition in the 1850s and 1860s. U.S. participation in the slave trade was banned in 1807 and strengthened in 1819. The Atlantic slave trade conducted by European traders on the West African coast involved purchasing slaves with goods like guns, alcohol, and cowrie shells. Slavery in Africa was practiced through capturing people in wars or as punishment, with some victims being kidnapped. Historians note that slaves in traditional African societies were often absorbed into families or local armies, with treatment generally less harsh than in the New World plantations. The slave trade in Africa led to turmoil, warfare, and instability in West Africa. The exchange of slaves for guns fueled conflicts, incentivizing warring parties to seek new captives. This warfare, loss of millions of productive individuals, and psychological damage weakened Africa, leaving it ill-prepared for future challenges. The slave trade in Africa led to warfare, loss of millions of people, and psychological damage, weakening the continent. By 1870, European powers were preparing to colonize Africa, despite the presence of strong indigenous political entities like the kingdom of Ashanti and Buganda. By the 1870s, African kingdoms like Ashanti and Buganda had strong central governments, advanced infrastructure, and growing trade. Buganda, for example, was a naval power on Lake Victoria with a powerful king and a strong army. Secondary empires, relying on European military technology, were also emerging, promoting the spread of Islam in sub-Saharan Africa. Islam had been spreading slowly in West Africa through trade contacts and had made larger gains in northeastern Africa through trade and Arab immigration. The expansion of colonial powers in Africa was driven by popular and political pressure, as well as business interests seeking to exploit the continent's resources.
